title: Genomic Instability and DNA Repair Mechanisms
summary: Comprehensive overview of genomic instability, DNA damage mechanisms, repair pathways, and their clinical implications in cancer and other diseases.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Genomic Instability and DNA Repair Mechanisms

Genomic instability is a central hallmark of cancer and is increasingly recognized as a driver of neurodegeneration, immune dysfunction, and premature aging. It refers to an increased tendency of alterations in the genome—ranging from single nucleotide changes to large-scale chromosomal rearrangements. This instability results from continuous DNA damage and defective repair mechanisms. DNA integrity is safeguarded by complex, evolutionarily conserved repair systems, which, when compromised, accelerate the accumulation of mutations, fuel malignant transformation, and promote resistance to therapy.
DNA is constantly exposed to damaging agents, both endogenous and exogenous. Cells typically experience tens of thousands of DNA lesions per day.

items: DNA replication errors: Can cause mismatches, insertions, or deletions—especially at microsatellite regions.
Tautomeric shifts: Lead to non-standard base pairing, increasing point mutation risk.
Depurination/depyrimidination: Spontaneous hydrolysis removes purines or pyrimidines, leaving abasic sites.
Deamination reactions: Cytosine → Uracil, 5-methylcytosine → Thymine (a frequent site of somatic mutation in cancer)
ROS-induced damage: Oxidative stress from mitochondrial respiration or inflammation leads to oxidized bases (e.g., 8-oxoG) and strand breaks.
Ultraviolet (UV) radiation: Induces pyrimidine dimers (thymine dimers, 6-4 photoproducts).
Ionizing radiation (X-rays, gamma rays): Causes single- and double-stranded breaks and base modifications.
Chemical mutagens: Alkylating agents, nitrosamines, benzopyrenes (from tobacco smoke), etc.
Infectious agents: Viruses such as HPV (E6/E7 disrupt p53/Rb), EBV, HBV, and Helicobacter pylori contribute to chronic genomic stress.

content.text: Efficient repair mechanisms ensure cell survival and suppress mutagenesis. These systems are tailored to specific types of DNA damage.

items: Fixes small, non-distorting lesions (oxidative, alkylated, or deaminated bases).
Involves: Glycosylase removes damaged base, AP endonuclease cleaves backbone, DNA polymerase β inserts correct base, DNA ligase seals the nick.
Removes bulky DNA adducts (e.g., thymine dimers, benzopyrene).

items: Telomeres are protective caps of repetitive DNA at chromosome ends.
With each division, telomeres shorten → replicative senescence or crisis.
Telomerase (TERT) is reactivated in ~90% of cancers to enable unlimited growth.

content.text: Genomic instability and impaired DNA repair are foundational in both cancer biology and systemic aging. The integrity of the genome is continually challenged, but cells possess elegant repair systems to prevent catastrophe. When these fail, the consequences are profound—resulting in malignancy, immune dysfunction, or degenerative diseases. With the expansion of precision oncology, targeting DNA repair defects has evolved from a biological insight to a therapeutic mainstay. Emerging technologies—from genome editing to AI-guided interpretation—will further enhance our ability to detect, model, and correct genomic instability.
